editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.name: Hannah Bredar

respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: The bride, a comedy. Acted in the year 1638. at the private house in Drury-lane by their majesty's servants.

lg.l: — Nec turpe marito est
Aspera pro charo bella tulisse thoro.

div.p: London. Printed by R. H. for Laurence blaikelocke and are to be sold at his shop at the sign of the sugarloaf next temple bar in Fleetstreet. 1640.

div.head: To the generalty of his noble friends, gentlemen of the several honourable houses the inns of court ▪
div.p:
I have presumed thus upon you, to countenance my shame fact bride; who now she is pressed blusheth to appear in public, through fear she hath of a new danger from public censure. She is here dressed according to mine own desire and intention; without
ought taken from her that myself thought ornament; nor supplied with any thing which I valued but as rags. Your favourable opinion, and your acceptance of her into your protection, will take off her fears, and make her present herself front laeto: and the honour that you do me thereby will add: to those many engagements that bind me always to declare myself

closer.signed: Your most thankful servant. Thomas Nabbes.

list.item: Theophilus. His son, supposed only his foster son.
Mrs. ferret. His wife, imperious over her husband.
Three of four blades. Wild roaring fellows.
Horten. An owner of rarities and antiquities.

lg.l: Vacation still: so little custom comes
To buy our merchandise, and fill our rooms,
It would persuade us but for after hope
Of better takings quite to shut up shop.
But what's the reason? have we no good ware?
Or do the sights and motions in the fair
Please better with their cheap rates? 'tis not fit
That we should set so low a prize on wit.
For what we shall present you with today
The bride, we wish you not t'expect a play,
Wherein a nestle-cock, or youth oth' town
(Born to more state than wit) is a gallant grown:
When one amongst you laughing at the elf
And at his gullery, thinks upon himself.
Perhaps there will be some concluding that
A person or a place is pointed at;
Such make that satire which the pure intent
Of th' author meant but harmless merriment;
Who only labours here in what he can
T'express a citizen a gentleman.
Mark well the weaving and the dressing, the●
Liking the stuff we hope you'll come again.

div.head: The first scene.
div.stage: Enter old Goodlove, and Theophilus very sad.

sp.speaker: Goodlove.
sp.l: I say, no more of this,
I'll have no brow contracted into wrinkles
Upon my wedding day: a day of mirth;
And thou standest like a melancholic figure
Of weeping penitence, when joy should dress
Thy cheeks in dimples; it is prodigious
That thou shouldst only
Wear mourning at my nuptials, that have fostered
Thee from an infant; bred thee to a man;
Ranked thee with gentlemen, and made thee thought
To be what thou appearest; and thou to grieve
For what I count my happiness!

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Pray sir construe it
Th' expression of my duty. To your love
Were I possessed of many selves I owe them.
That love hath caused this passion out of fear▪
Your reputation in the act will suffer
rumor is apt to prey upon occasion:
And if the rude mouths of the multitude
Catch hold on a report, they'll multiply it;
And make it. grow to scandal. You an old man
Will marry a young woman.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: Who calls me old! Dost thou? Now by my beard
(Is't not turned black again? I should be loath
To swear by a false colour) I am young,
Like a new spring grown out of a barren winter.
I've likewise strength and activeness: look here else.Seems to caper and hurt his foot.
Beshrew't, the floor's uneven: would 'twere mended
I'll have my corns cut too. Child we must dance
Always at weddings. Am I again a bridegroom!
And shall I not be lusty?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Pray sir, do not
Flatter your weakness, and decay of strength.
Your age begins to grow to a disease:
And can you then express such youthful appetite
Without being censured?

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: Pray no more dissuasion
Besides my will there is a reason for it:
And thou hast cause to joy, she brings a portion
Will be a large addition to thy state,
Which I but live t'increase. I have no heir
Save thee? nor will get any: shalt have all.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Your welfare sir to me
Is an inheritance above any state
Fortune can bless me with. Which to preserve
My knees should grow fast to some hallowed pavement,
Till mine own dissolution, and no thoughts
Busy my mind but prayers. Sir consider
The difference 'twixt your disability,
And her so hopeful fruitfulness. T' increase
And propagate was the best end of marriage.
Then if the means be wanting, the end cannot
Be perfected: and some in scruple stick not
To call it sin.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: More urging! when I am dead
thou shalt have her too. Ha! dost startle at it?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Why that would make even your ashes infamous.
And tempt the idle gazers on't to scratch
Libels upon your marble. 'twould be construed
That she in youthful heat longing for what
Your cold defects denied her, had enjoyed me
To lustful satisfaction, when she should
Have warmed your bed, and after married me
To prevent farther rumor. Nay sir more.
Hath she not settled her desire already
Upon some one of more proportioned years?
'Twere rare if such a beauty of that growth,
Should have her maiden thoughts untouched with th' appetite
Of what instinct doth teach, though she were barred
Even all converse, so much as not to know
The difference of a sex.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: A causeless jealousy
She's noted to have more perfections
Lodged in her rich mind, than the outward structure
Though beautiful doth promise: she inherits
Her parents virtues, and her education
Hath been their only care. I know she's free
From the least thought may stain her purity.
Therefore no more.

div.head: The second scene.
div.stage: To them raven, and a little after him monsieur Kickshaw.

sp.p: Is my bride yet come cousin?

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Not yet sir. Monsieur Kickshaw the French cook's come to prepare dinner.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: He's welcome; let me see him
I'll have the feast seasoned with all variety
Of choice delights.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: To me they will not relish;
But like those pills which an unwilling patient
doubting their virtue takes, and turns the medicine
Into a worse disease.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: Monsieur you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.l: Me tank you monsieur.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: I presume you'll show your best cunning.

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.p: Me make you de French dish; de pulpatone; de frigasie; de gran Kickeshaw an de kickshaw royal; de macaroon: and two tree dozen ting more for your wedding.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: Pray cousin take him first into the cellar.

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.p: Remerce monsieur. Me drink two tree cup a your claret a your vite vine sall make a me lusty.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: I shall thankfully consider your pains.

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.p: Monsieur ven a me work is done, you give a me leave to dance two tree four dance, an kiss a devench two tree four time. O de French man love a de fine vench vary well. You be de old man monsieur, and you love a de young vench: me make your de dish sall get this child.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: Too many on conscience.

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.l: If de madam love me, me get twenty.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: To your business good monsieur.

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.l: Dat be good business, better den go to my work. Exit.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Observe you sir this fellow! one that ought
To be kicked into manners how he taunts you?
'Twill be the streets discourse, the conduits lecture:
And not an idle tongue but will abuse.
Your reverend name, which hitherto hath awed
Th' unbridled rabble.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: Once more I command thee
Leave off this counsel, growing but from fear,
That will admit no reason. Cousin raven
Hasten my bride: she makes my patience tire
With so much expection. And hark you cousin. Whisper.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: My sun of joys eclipsed, and all the hopes
My fancy painted, by this accident
Are blotted out. How have I merited
Of heaven thus to be punished! But I must not
Tax providence with an injustice to me,
That have deserved worse curses for neglect
of my religious duties. Only he,
My foster father to possess those sweets
Love promised my inheritance! Were't another,
I'd from his rude hands snatch her in the church,
Before the powerful words should knit that knot
Nothing but death dissolves.

div.head: The third scene.
div.stage: To them Maligo and Rhenish.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: Senior maligo a most welcome guest.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Your servant senior.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: And Mr. Rhenish.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.p: The Spanish and Dutch merchants! send there be no wars at the wedding.

sp.speaker: Rhen.
sp.l: We come to witness your solemnities.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Welcome Mr. Rhenish: and since you are come so early let's spend the time in conference about the wines we lately spoke of. Exeunt. Theo. and raven remaining.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Cousin you're sad. Would I might know the reason,
I'll help to put it from you.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Cousin raven,
Since love, not blood, hath made you wear that title,
Though 'tis a secret I would gladly hide,
To you I will impart it. Sent with gifts
To the fair maid that this day must be bride
To the old man, my treacherous eyes conveyed
Flames to my heart from hers: which being fixed
Upon me, shot their magic influence
Of love with such a violence, that I took
Th' impression ere my bosom was prepared
And tempered for it.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: This may be a ground
For me to work on.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Duty now and honesty
fought with my passions, and enforced them back
To their unwilling prison: though her eye,
Look, gesture; and at parting when I took
Her hand to kiss it: than she held mine hard:
For all these invitations to their liberty
I durst not free them; but concealed even that
Perhaps she wished to know.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: How can you doubt it?
They were all signals that you should assault,
And she would yield 'tis but a modest custom
For men to woo. 'tis women's only pride
To have men court them, not to be denied.
Indeed it was your fault.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: My virtue rather.
Should I like the ingrateful serpent, sting
The bosom that hath warmed me into life?
Desire shall burst me first. Yet I must tell you,
I am resolved to give my passions
This satisfaction. When the bridal ceremonies
Have had their consummation, I will travail
And leave the cause behind. You may reveal it
When I am gone. I shall be praised or pitied,
For none can blame me.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: None! Yes all that hear it.
Who will not tax your indiscretion,
And want of knowing what belongs to man,
That will deny yourself that right, perhaps
None but yourself can challenge. we are warranted
To be indulgent to ourselves so far
As work our own contents by any means
Conscience or law calls just. Then if the time
Prevent it not, try your success: be sudden:
Steal her away and marry her.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Tempt me not
Out of my passion into one more dangerous.
'Twere but a just correction if I killed thee;
That would instruct me to an act of error,
Repentance could scarce win a pardon for.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: My counsel's worth a better fee. Perhaps
You fear some treachery in me. Clear your understanding,
I'll prove you ought to do it, and I to aid you.
You are his foster son, and I his kinsman.
You he intends his heir, and yet he must not
Neglect me altogether. When they are married
She'll find one to get children.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Thou art base
In thy suspect of her; and but for peace
(To which this day ought to be consecrate)
It should be punished.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: You're too violent.
Be calm, and understand demonstrative reason,
Children being born, then are you disinherited.
When marrying her there's an estate will follow
Worth thousands: for she is the only child
Her parents ever had.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: And why should you
Advise to this, and aid it?

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: What more police.
Could I be guilty of? When his displeasure
Hath cast you of (For that way sure he'll punish
The injury) stand not I fair to be
Possessed of what you lose, the old man's favour?
Were you the only object of my hate,
The good I do myself would make the act
Show of sufficient malice: but my love
Guiding me to't —

div.head: The fourth scene.
div.stage: To them Goodlove, Maligo and Rhenish: and a little after them justice Ferret and his wife.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: 'Tis well I am prevented;
My rashness else had executed justice
upon thy guilt. Forbear to tempt me farther.
Thy friendship's but the shadow of a true one
Darest urge such counsel, goodness cannot choose but blush at.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Howsoever you receive it
I will attempt it. I'll prepare the bride
With this discovery: if she hath desires
She'll some way give them liberty. The old man
I then will prepossess with jealousy;
And so endear me to him, that my ends
Stand always fair in their opinions.
A cunning villain must pretend to save.
When most of all he doth intend a graveExit.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: I like the rates: may the wines please as well
I'll not repent my bargain.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Trust me sir you have the best sack of Spain.

sp.speaker: Rhen.
sp.p: And Rhenish the swan hath none better: yet there's that will make the crookedst Horner in the lane speak Latin with the beadle of vintners hall.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: Mr. justice ferret,
This was a large expression of your love
To come over the water:

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: 'Twas my wife's desire.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: Kind mistress ferret.

sp.speaker: M. Fe.
sp.p: Sir, the respects I bear you, and the obedience I owe my husband that commanded it, brought me over willingly to offer my service to so noble a friend.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: Your courtesies overcome me.

sp.speaker: M. Fe.
sp.p: A rot on the best linings of your three piled durable; your everlasting almanac of high days, feasts and sessions: was it my desire? Thou liest thou wrong side of a lawyer turned outwards: I had better business at home. I could have seen if mother whirl had spun the last pound of flax I sent her, or called at knocks the weavers for my new napkins. I have no maids to cudgel their tasks out of. Indeed I can hardly keep any for such a goat as thou art.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: Are ye offended with your husband Mrs. ferret?

sp.speaker: M. Fer.
sp.p: Obedience forbid it; my head: or if I may use the honourable phrase here without offence, my cap of maintenance.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: No no sir; she was but excusing a few faults.

sp.speaker: M. Fer.
sp.p: How sir lubber, must the world take notice by you that I have faults or modesty to excuse them? I'll make thee complain a month of the fairies for this: the fairies of my nails I mean; and pretend pinching for pissing in thy shoes, or such night uncleanness.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Sweet wife forbear a little. Thou wilt vex away thy eating stomach, and here will be excellent cheer.

sp.speaker: M. Fer.
sp.p: So, so: I thought a city seast with a ram-mutton pasty, and a twelve nooked custard, made with carrier's eggs and the out scrapings of isinglass, must tempt you to the charge of six pence over, and six pence back again. Which with an addition of clerk's fees shared, and some garrisoned Westphalian neat's tongue or red dear pie out of my chamber cupboard, might have been an entertainment for the masters of the parish in your own dining room; and all have been paid for too with the return of half emptied bottles.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Your wife Mr. ferret hath called something to mind deserves a chiding.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Fie no sir: she is somewhat shrewish at home, but the best wife abroad —

sp.speaker: M. Fer.
sp.p: Fie, sweet heart now you flatter. 'tis virtue enough in us to be obedient and dutiful: we should lay ourselves under our husband's feet if they command it. But I'll exalt myself or somewhat else above your head, you malkin of suburb authority set up only to fright crows from the carrion of the common wealth, that it may lie still and corrupt government. Your worship had best bind my tongue to the peace, my nails should soon bail it. Soft music.

div.head: The fifth scene
div.stage: To them father, mother, raven, bride, and maids attending her.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: My bride come?
The welcomest guest that ever blessed this roof.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.l: Joy crown ye both.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: May your wish be prophetic.
But why is she so sad?

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: 'Tis only custom.
Maids have their fears which by degrees must leave them.

sp.speaker: M. Fe.
sp.p: May she make him a happy wife; and prove obedient from my example.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: Salute my bride son: she should be thy joy
As well as mine.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I better shall express
Her entertainment in my pious wishes,
Than any compliment I will be ready
To pay you my best duty. Goodlove and Raven whisper.

sp.speaker: Bride,
sp.l: Love you mean sir;
Give it no other name, might I own that
And call it my possession, soon this melancholy
Should leave it's mansion, and a bride's full joy
Inhabit here. You surely do repine;
And it may be this act begets your fear
Of being dispossessed a father's love.
Which he must now in some proportion
Confer on me.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Let me with reverence swearOffers to kiss her hand
By this white hand —

sp.speaker: Bride,
sp.l: Let me prevent your oath;
Or swear by another book. Perhaps 'twill be
The last warm kiss my lips shall ever feel.Kiss.
I do believe you love me.Weeps.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: How shall I
Interpret this? how hard she clasped my hand,
And pressed my lips? as wishing their conjunction
Might be eternal. Tears with her last words fell:
And in their silent oratory taught me
To know myself more wretched by the knowledge
Of what should make me happy.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: Can this be?

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: It hath both possibility and circumstance
To make it probable. Good sir observe
Their discontents: how they do sympathize,
and meet each other. Pray sir let them have
An opportunity; I'll be the spy:
And call you to their billing.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: 'Tis well counselled
If 'tplease you gentlemen I have within
Some rarities, whose fight shall be your business
Till we are ready. Sweet you shall forbear them
Till you are made their mistress. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Whether will you go? Theo. offers to follow.
Wast not my plot to get this liberty
That you might put your purpose into act
If you have any? Why do you delay it?
You see she's willing; I prepared her to it.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Willing to what good cousin?

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: To be your bride.

sp.speaker: Bride.
sp.l: My blushes speak consent: then if you please
Prevent prevention. My desires were never
Settled on any other, though I durst not
Reveal my passions awed by feminine custom,
And my strict parents eyes. If you'll receive me,
The desperate state of my cross fortune arms me
To any enterprise you'll be my guide in

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I shall be tempted to neglect that duty
I would not rashly violate, to possess
All that my wish can covet.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: You may hereafter
Discourse your loves. Play not away th' occasion.
sp.p: Here's the key of the back gate: take water presently, and away to the — whispers — I'll follow, get ye a licence and see all dispatched. Fear not pursuit: that I'll hinder. Exeunt.
So, the foundations laid on which I'll build
Myself a fortune, and with better safety
Then making him away: yet he must not marry her.
That were t'enable him if my villainy
Should be discovered to revenge and punish it.

div.head: The sixth scene.
div.stage: To him Goodlove, father, mother, Ferret, mrs. Ferret, Maligo, and Rhenish.

sp.p: The old man! aid me now hypocrisy, or all miscarries. O sir I have searched for you all the house over.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: Hast observed any thing?

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.p: I left them here so close condoling. They are questionless stolen to some private place. I'll scent them out, and bring you word.
I must absent myself for fear my joy
For this fair entrance doth discover me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: Father in expectation I have suddenly
Bethought me of a business.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.l: Pray what is't?

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: You see I am old; unfit for such a bride.
Suppose I make a resignation,
And give my right up to another man,
One that your daughter and yourself should like of.
What if my son were bridegroom? 'twere a match
Would carry more proportion.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.l: None more gladly,
So you'll confer upon him an estate
Answering her portion.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: It shall be considered of.
We'll know their likings.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Will you not marry her yourself then after all these preparations? Why sir the world takes notice of it, and it may concern your credit.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: Your husband counsels well Mrs. Ferret.

sp.speaker: M. Fe.
sp.p: I cannot in obedience but allow of his wisdom. Thou changeling nursed with the milk of an ass whence thou derivest thy great empty noddle: must you hinder a good motion? Are there not cuckolds enough already?

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: Where's the bride cousin? Raven returns.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.p: Vanished sir, not to be found. They are questionless run away together: the water gate is fast locked, and the key without. You were doubtful sir, and would hardly give credit to my relation.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.l: How! stolen away together! what plots are these?

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: Yours sir, to undo the reputation
Of an old man.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.l: Rather your own, to ruin
My only comfort.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Proceed you sir in your late motion and this difference will soon find a reconciliation. Is not the gentleman his only son.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: No son of mine, but the most monstrous birth
Of base ingratitude that ever made
Charity frozen. I found him in the fields,
An infant almost starved, and bred him up.
It seems for this.

sp.speaker: Mother
sp.l: Alas our child's undone.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.l: Pursue the villain. If the extremity
Of law can do it, I will hang him for't.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: I should be glad of that.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.l: If I can prove sir your least knowledge makes you
A party in't, your state or mine shall crack for't.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: Do you sir threaten me in mine own house. ?
My credit's more at stake, then that I should
Be calm: but once I give you privilege.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.l: Come let's 'To water: we perhaps may take them.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Yes at the tower questionless. Exeunt. Father and mother.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Sir if I find them in my precinct.

sp.speaker: M. Fer.
sp.p: What will you do? If thou dost the least wrong to the loving couple, though I burn for it, I will roast thee alive and sell thy greasy kidneys for kitchenstuff. Kickshaw enters with plate under his cloak.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: A good proceeding hitherto.

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.p: No vench, no veding? Me bid you adieu monsieur; you no need a me varke.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: Farewell monsieur. Reward him cousin.

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.p:
Here be reward: two, tree silver dish, and tree, four spoon make monsieur a gentleman an buy define vench beyond
de water. Me no stay for de reward. Exit.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: Ha hah hah he. Laughs.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Why laugh you sir? make you no more account of so great an injury?

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: They're gone: and now I'll tell ye gentlemen,
I knew the boy did love her, and I meant
He only should enjoy her; but pretended
Myself would marry her, thereby to work
A greater portion out of her covetous father;
And to insinuate myself into
A perfect knowledge of his true estate.
Now since h'hath played the wag, preventing me
Of mine own plot, you all shall in and witness
My act of love to him: I'll instantly
Confirm him my full heir, reserving something
For you my kinsman: whom I desire
Use your best diligence to find them out,
And bring them home, but coupled. And you gentlemen
Dispense with this day's accident, your cheer
Tomorrow shall be doubled. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: How is this?
My plot's prevented too; curse on the charm
That witcheth you to love him. Bring them home,
But coupled: fine employment. Yet 'tis well
You tell me your intent. My brain must work
Some more successful mischief that may hit.
No villain can prosper without wit.

div.stage: Exit.

div.head: The first scene.
div.stage: Squirrel, and after him a drawer.

sp.speaker: Squir.
sp.p:
Your diligence knaves, or I shall canvas your pole davies, deafen not a gallant with your anon anon fit, to make him stop his cares at an over-reckoning. Can a mansion purchased
and paid for be converted into a house of entertainment, and subsist without comings in and goings out? Now sir what say you?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: The reckoning sir for Mr. serge the mercer, and the scrivener's wife, that have been these two hours in the yellow bedchamber.

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.l: And what had they?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: A dish of collops and eggs, and wine.

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.l: Sixteen shillings! 'tis well.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: But her husband had half a choir of paper and bastard by himself in the bullshead: which would hardly keep him employed below stairs; he was going up to peep through the key hole.

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.p: Saucy scrivener! peep through a key hole! shouldst have had him by the cares.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: His peeping through a hole cost them long since.

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.l: And this came freely!

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: He wondered sir it was no more. Exit. Dra.

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.p: Go carry the blades in the lion a pottle of sack from me: their roaring must be maintained out of my profit. They are good procurers; and help now and then to stane of an over heated citizen that pursues his game, too eagerly. Though my holiday squires of the city bring me in most gain, my free knights of the suburbs, the errants of Lincoln-inn fields, where their rendezvous makes the gunpowder house terrible, and the smock tribute due to their order is daily and nightly exacted: these I say are the best maintainers of my profits occasion; and squirrel must venture cracking to maintain them whilst his sign and bush lasts.

div.head: The second scene.
div.stage: To him Theophilus and bride. You're welcome sir.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: The master of the house!

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.p: The poor owner of some goods and chattels; movables and immovables, with a small stock to drive a trade.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: We would desire the use of a room.

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.l: You shall be accommodated.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: We expect a friend; till he comes this may serve.

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.l: What you please sir. A towel sirrah quickly. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Thou seemest sweet heart as if th' hadst fears within thee.
We may securely now discourse our loves,
And weary time with words, till we are fit
To act our wishes.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: The fullness of my joys
Happening so sudden ere I was prepared
To taste them with an appetite, hath bred
A surfeit in me.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Now you smell of flattery
I would not have you court what you possess
With any attribute above its merit.
If my being yours you count your happiness,
Let us be sudden to confirm ourselves
Mutually happy, ere our parents rage
Can reach us to prevent it.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: That word parents.
Makes me reflect on my ingratitude:
Being greater far than infamous records
Did ever punish; and like pleasant dreams
My joys are changed to nothing.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Sudden dumbs:
Whence are they? to myself I am not guilty
Of a behaviour that should merit this.
I prithee let me blush, and kiss away
The clouds hang on thy brow. No discontent
Should interpose where equal love hath mixed
Equal desires; and for the noble end
No base dependence. For could I but think
Thy soul did harbour any bastard thought
Which goodness might not father, I would back
To my disgrace; and confidently meet
My parent's anger; all th' affronts of rumor;
And what the rabble pleased rather than stay
To nurse it to a growth.

sp.speaker: The
sp.l: Then pray return;
But not to your disgrace; all shall be thrown
Upon my guilt. And though my love (Unstained
with the least blemish of impure affection)
Gave th' act allowance, I'll belie myself,
And say I did enforce you; which the law
May punish with my life. I'll give it up,
To end th' affliction of my soul, divided
Betwixt love to you, and duty to that man
I have so wronged.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Can love admit such scruples?
Or is't thy coldness? I was too too credulous.
But the necessity denied more trial.
Here's a pretence indeed.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Can there be greater?
Ingratitude's a monster. Shall I then
Repay that man with injury, that gave
My almost starved life warmth, and made me breathe
Though to be miserable

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Thou dost surely
Want the best part of man, and art not capable.
Of resolution. Such a coward spirit
Lodgeth not here. I now suspect thy worth,
And blame my rashness.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Why should I be taxed
With such defect? Know then I dare deserve you
By any enterprise that may be credible.
Invention cannot fancy an employment
I would not manage to confirm my love
Worthy your best opinion, only this
My conscience frights me from.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Why then farewell.
Passion will guide me somewhere , goodness guard me
From a despair; and whatsoever end
I am disposed for, I'll remember thee
Deniest thyself good in denying me.

div.stage: Offers to go away.

div.head: The third scene.
div.stage: To them the drawer with a towel.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: What's your wine sir?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Presently. Stay. Pulls back bride.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: Your pleasure sir. Bride weeps.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I mean not you.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: I know your meaning sir. Exit. Drawer.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Why should those pearls be wasted,
Till they enrich my funeral? Distraction
Hurries my thoughts, and hindereth them from ordering
Any resolve. Have I proceeded hitherto?
And shall I now give back? The infamy
Sticks on my name already; and the stain
Thrown on it by the black mouthed multitude
For being in grateful, by bare satisfaction
Cannot be washed away. Her virtue likewise
Will be suspected. I must therefore on
Since reason prompts me to it. Love shall excuse
The act, and my neglect of other dues.
Sweet I am now resolved.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Resolved! to what?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: To consummate our wishes.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Now I think on't
'Tis better not. I find my flame abated:
My love's not half so violent, I can stay,
And try you first.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: How's this? why will you now
Change your intent that seemed so resolute?
'Twill make us be the subject of discourse,
And libelling ballads; every gossip's feast
Will make mirth from our shame.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: No matter for't
I now begin t'examine what's in you
So taking an indifferent handsome fra●;
the superficies neatly varnished over.
In it should dwell a soul rich as the building
Doth promise to the eye; but I suspect it.
Thy actions suit not with a noble spirit.
Thy love's but wanton passion, not the virtue
Should give it warrant. He that would be mine,
Must in his mind as well as outward shine.
Again farewell. Offers again to go.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Stay: I have fooled myself
Into a maze of errors, and do want
M' instructive part to guide me. All my faculties
Of soul are puzzled, and at every turning.
Do mate themselves with doubts. Why should you feign
This cruelty to kill me, when my joys
Were almost strengthened in the life you gave them,
So far as not to fear a new relapse?
Having corrected all the accidents
Of my diseased love, will you now desist
To make a perfect cure?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Medicines applied
To an unwilling or distrustful patient
Their working's hindered. You have ill received
The means; and what succeeds, yourself is guilty of;
No cruelty of mine.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Are you resolved then
To send me back to my first misery?
And anew make me wretched?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Till confirmed
There's merit in you.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Is my want of that
Only suspected by you? Hear me first,
And then farewell. May I be cursed beyond
Recovery by my penitence; let heaven
Never make me master of a wish that may
Include my least good, if I marry you —

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Until your parents free consent,
And the good liking of that injured man
allow it public ceremony

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Thou canst not
Figure a more impossibility.
It must be never then. Call in thy vow;
The rashness will dispense wich't

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: That might give
A new occasion for your cruel wit
To tax me with new weakness. Know I can
Be man as well as lover; and am fixed
In my resolve, beyond the power of change
By any passion.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: I have played too long
With the false shadow of my happiness,
And mocked away the substance. By my love
Zealous as ever kindled a chaste flame
In any maiden's breast, I but dissembled
To try thy patience, and beget discourse.
I am so well confirmed in my opinion
Of thy desert, that should a thousand tongues
Swollen with detraction, break their tumerous bags,
Venting from thence the most corrupted malice
That ever made man infamous to me
It should be flattering praise.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Did you dissemble?
Could she who through her eyes conveyed her heart,
And the assurance of her best desires
When other means were silenced; she that taught
My equal passion to interpret looks,
Tears, smiles, and read in those dumb characters
Her soul, dissemble? or with any counterfeit
Disturb his joy that only from her truth
Derives it true possession? Jealousy
May then be warranted, since 'tis a virtue
Noble and masculine when justly grounded.
Was not your love dissembled? meant you not
To make a property of these proceedings
For some ends of your own? Dispose yourself
A ●ur will guides you; 'twill but make my life
somewhat more tedious wanting your society:
Besides whom I renounce all woman kind.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: I man besides thee. Do not tempt thy fate
Too far beyond a reconciliation
With opportunity; as yet it serves.
If this day give thee not possession of me
Never expect it. I shall find a place
To keep out shame. In some chaste fellowship
I'll learn to pay religious vows to heaven.
And pray since here we cannot, we may be
Happy hereafter in eternity.Weeps.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Dissolve not with those tears my passive heart
That weeps within me. They will almost tempt me
To worse than sacrilege. Anon we will
Consult and practise something.

div.head: The fourth scene.
div.stage: To them squirrel. After him raven.

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.p: By the description he makes of you a gentleman below inquires for you. I was not curious to ask your name, but I know him.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: My cousin raven!

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.l: The same sir.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Pray direct him to us.

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.l: What's your wine sir?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: When he comes.

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.p: This is sure some hidebound student, that proportions his expense by his pension; and wencheth at Tottenham court for stewed prunes and cheesecakes. He's not acquainted with the generous way, and I shall have the less scruple to cozen him. Exit.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Be not so cloudy sweet; our sun of joy
May shine at full, and clear those dusky mists;
Obscure it for a season. Welcome cousin
Unto our expectation.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: The wine ●oye.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: Anon anon sir: by and by.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Cousin the news? how go matters?

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: The tempest's laid, but they are scattered by it.
Some to the tower; to Pancras others run.
Noise fills the rooms within, and in the street
The rabble is convented; where a jury
Of wide mouthed oyster wives, to whom the foreman
A one legged ballad singer opens tunably
The merry case, not only do acquit you,
But praise the act; and swear a ballad of it
Would out sell all the libels ever yet
M. P. subscribed to.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: 'Tis an act indeedDrawer ●ers with wife and exit.
Deserves reproach

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Deserves a chronicle
A legend of delight. Which when 'tis read
By the learned youth of Hogsden after supper,
Shall cause such laughter amongst th' attentive family,
That Cheapside wives shall curse the noise, for souring
The market women's cream and buttermilk.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: You're very pleasant cousin. Some man's jealousy.
Would soon interpret it to be but scorn.
What you intend it —

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Cousin it is my zeal
Makes me thus light and airy; yet rather
Than my behaviour should give way unto
The least suspicion, I'll put on a shape
Of like dejectedness, as seems to clothe
Your melancholic bride; but how 'twould show
'Th' occasion makes it doubtful. If she'll weep
Upon her wedding day, let it not be
But that she apprehends th' ensuing night
Brings on her joyful fears. Cousin let's drink
A health to the effect: a jolly boy
Will follow fear not.Drinks

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Yet the cause is hindered.
Pray let your counsels in our danger be
movers unto more serious thoughts and actions.
Our peace is not yet settled; and we doubt
What the success may be which our proceedings
Are destined to.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Success! the best that time,
And th' application of endeavours can
Crown your desires with. Yet I must confess
Your parents storm, and threaten death if law
By any trick can urge it. But the old man
Seems to forgive you; only his intent
Is to dispose his state some other way
Then leave the least part yours. Which to comply for
With any least submission I should rather
Banish myself his sight, and cancelling
All th' obligations of indebted duty,
Scorn to be flattered into payment of it.
Cousin be ruled by me; confirm yourself
In this possession. You may find delights
Enjoying one another though restrained
A general liberty. Get into the country
Remote enough, but where you may receive
Weekly intelligence and means from me;
Which I'll supply you with in a proportion
For moderate expense. As things grow ripe
I can inform you. As it hath been ever,
It shall be still my care to do you offices
(For mine own ends.)

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: You have my dearest cousin
Given large testimony of your love;
Requital must be studied. But for this
You have advised to, a quite different course
Is here resolved on, and my ●ow hath sealed it.
I ●st return to labour a consent
From those I have so wronged; which if denied me,
I never must enjoy, what I desire
Above myself.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Consent. 'twould soon be had,
If I prevent it not. A noise within.
What noise is that?
Perhaps some that pursue you; hide yourselves ▪
Here's an inner room. Puts them into another room.

div.head: The fifth scene.
div.stage: To him squirrel peeping.

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.p: So, so, this is right gentlemen; one for another. Yet she looks not like carrion of Mr. ravens leaving; I have seldom known him turn over any flesh to another that hath not been sufficiently tainted.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.p: This accident whate'er it was hath gained me an opportunity. Squirrel thou must be intelligent and trusty. Hast observed?

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.l: Why is she a wench?

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.p: There's a question now to bring thy wit in question, and condemn thee for a puny politic in the smock state. What blades are in the house?

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.l: Rashbe, Spilman, poinard, and others.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: And they made the noise?

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.l: Right sir.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Will they attempt?

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.l: Any thing for you sir. Shall it be an affront?

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.p: More, more: send them up; and apply thyself with cunning as thou expectest ever to thrive by the cost sins of wenching.

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.p: I have known you Mr. raven a bird of the flesh these many years, and if I should not respect an old standard.

div.stage: Exit.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Away then to the execution.
Cousin our fears was causeless. The●. and bride come forth again.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Had they been
Such as it spoke them, we might well have stayed
And yielded to them. We had only seemed
Compelled to what we free must perform.

div.head: The sixth scene.
div.stage: To them the blades.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Have you business with any here sir?

sp.speaker: 1 Bla.
sp.l: I do not use to answer sir. Sweet lady.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: What fellow's this?

sp.speaker: 1 Bla.
sp.p: Fellow? one that will admit no fellow sir. Fellow! Fellow yourself.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: More! I suspect some rudeness. Pray cousin call the master of the house.

sp.speaker: 2 Bla.
sp.p: The master of the house is the master of the house; but we will master both him and you unless you deliver.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: My purse?

sp.speaker: 3 Bla.
sp.l: Your she familiar sir; we would be familiar with her.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: You are foul mouthed

sp.speaker: 1 Bla.
sp.p: How sir citizen! do you think ere you are quite fledge in the nest, with the shell of your cuckoos eg● upon your head to confront us? We are blades; and blades must be scoured.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: What mean you sir?

sp.speaker: 2 Bla.
sp.l: Your servant sweet lady.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: She is none of your pleasure ladies, 'tis a wrong direction of your base thoughts.

sp.speaker: 3 Bla.
sp.p: Base! Cit. thou deservest the cane: but this lady's goodness commands thy pardon.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: You are mistaken sir, I have no skill
In th' art of prostitution.

sp.speaker: 1 Bla.
sp.l: You shall be instructed lady; 'tis the blade's profession.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Forbear your rudeness; if you must be wicked.
Let your temptations be directed where
The sin is grown to custom. Her chaste ears
Never received such sounds.

sp.speaker: 2 Bla.
sp.l: Come come, you must sweet lady.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: What sir?

sp.speaker: 1 Bla.
sp.p:
A long with us: we are company indeed. Who would 〈◊〉 Cit. (Whose teeth are rotten out with sweet meats his mother
brings him from goshippings) breathe upon her varnish for the promise of a dry neat's tongue and a pottle of Rhenish at the stillyard, when she may command a blade to toss and tumble her? and (If she should pawn a petticoat) beat such a fellow as this is till he hath redeemed it.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Advantage may do much; but I would wish ye
Desist, and be more civil: 'tis not th' odds else
Shall fright me from attempting to correct you.

sp.speaker: 2 Bla.
sp.l: Correct us! nay then along lady. One draws and stands at the door, whilst the other carry her away.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Help me sweet heart, will ye use violence?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Ye cowards, 'gainst an unarmed man!

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: May not I pass?

sp.speaker: 3 Bla.
sp.p: Not through me sir, unless you were a blade; the fraternity may claim some privilege.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Then arm me justice. Theo. throws his cloak on the others point; gets within him and takes away his sword.

sp.speaker: 3 Bla.
sp.l: Hold, for heaven's sake hold.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Thy life! I scorn it: 'tis too base to pay
A satisfaction; she must be redeemed
At a far higher rate. Exit.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: My wishes issue
In all things yet. Are you much hurt sir?

sp.speaker: 3 Bla.
sp.p: A scratch or so. If the rest scape no better, I shall believe there is more valour in some, then what's only shown at a Finsbury muster. Exit. Ent. Squi. hastily.

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.p: Your aid master raven, or we shall have murder done. The young gentleman sir, the young gentleman —Exit.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: I hope so, if my plot succeeds.
This was an unlooked business thrust upon me.
But I must practise my hypocrisy
With best art; else suspicion may discover.
The guilt that's in me. Sure he's dead by this time,
Unless his skin be proof against their points.
If one of them should fall, and he escape
The rest I will suborn to make his life
The laws. Thus villainy like a pregnant mother
From the success of one begets another. Exit.

div.head: The first scene.
div.stage: Theophilus beating in the blades before him; bride, raven and squirrel.

sp.speaker: 1 Bla.
sp.l: Hold hold; I am hurt.

sp.speaker: 2 Bla.
sp.l: I bleed too.

sp.speaker: 1 Bla.
sp.l: If my sword had had a point, I had paid him home.

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.l: I beseech you sir be pacified.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Sir if your house be a place privileged
For such abuses, it must be informed of,
That law may punish it. But for these shadows,
Mockshapes of valour; 'twere it not for staining
My innocent hands, I would compel your souls
Black as they are to give me satisfaction
As ye expire them.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Prithee sweet no more;
'Tis well th' art safe.

sp.speaker: 1 Bla.
sp.p: We do acknowledge an error sir; and for satisfaction sir and to preserve peace, our weapons shall be delivered up to the master of the house.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Mischief upon their baseness; how are they
Declined from men! I hoped one desperate thrust
Or stroke ere this had sent him to his quiet,
And cut off farther labour to contrive it;
It racks my invention. Yet I cannot rise
To what I aim at but by his ruin.

sp.speaker: 1 Bla.
sp.l: We hope you'll do the like sir.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: If I were confident of safety.
But you must give me leave being one that can
Command myself and passion. This with me
Serves as an instrument of peace, and may
Fright an intended mischief from me. Good sir
Retain their weapons as you'll answer it
At your own peril.

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.l: Surely Mr. raven, you were mistaken; this is no wench.

div.stage: Exit.

sp.speaker: 2 Bla.
sp.l: Baffled and hurt! we may revenge it sir.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Ye properties of men, made up of rags
And outside only, shoot your threats at those
That fear the bubbles. Think not here to triumph
As o'er your easy gulls, that must redeem
Their safeties from the danger of your furies,
By battering down with th' engine of their purse
Some sconce your drunken valour in a tavern
Hath built with sack.

sp.speaker: 3 Bla.
sp.l: So sir.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Be gone, for fear you urge me
To more impatience: yet my charity
Affords ye this good counsel. The world's full
Of brave employments for men capable.
You've persons, but want minds for actions
That might ennoble ye. Honour attends
On war; ye only call yourselves by names
Of captains and lieutenants here where peace
Is most secure, but when your drunken quarrels
Disturb her. Go to th'wars, and save the city
The chargeable repairing of their prisons.

sp.speaker: 1 Bla.
sp.l: We'll think upon your satire.

sp.speaker: 1 Bla.
sp.p: Take the scabbard too. My belt I'll pawn for a scarf to hang my arm in, that the not wearing of a sword may have pretence; till whose recovery I am degraded from a blade to a battoon. Exeunt the blades.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: How lovely shows this valour? That in men
There should be so much difference.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Why so sad coz? What think you on?

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: I was contriving mischief.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Mischief! 'gainst whom?

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: I shall betray myself.
A merry harmless mischief; whose relation
Shall make the ice of melancholic spleens
Dissolve with laughter. 'tis a pretty plot
Upon those roarers.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Pray impart it then.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: There is a passage in't unperfect yet
How apt is guilt to be its own discoverer?
I almost had spoiled all.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I do begin weighing the circumstance
To be possessed
With a suspect of his sincerity.
He's surely treacherous; and perhaps occasioned
The late attempt upon me, so to have
Removed the bar he fears might shut him out
From an inheritance I never coveted.
I must not be too credulous. What's the reason
You are so cloudy cousin? In your eyes
Methinks I read sad thoughts; your merry mischief
Promised more lightsomness.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: I cannot yet
Fancy a good conclusion; it hath passages
That would be a neat one. Are you cousin
Resolved on your return? or will you practise
As I advised?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Doth that concern your plot?

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: I mind no plots; my mind is only busy
To make you safe.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Safe! which way mean you cousin?

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Pray wrest it not. Suppose those baffled roarers
Should in revenge waylay you: they are mischievous;
And if you should miscarry —

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: No great matter:
There were an end of misery. You need not
Be much solicitous to prevent my danger;
Since on my death depends the assurance
Of an estate to you. When you enjoy it,
If my cold ashes might be capable
Of such expressions, they should dance for joy
Fortune had so rewarded you, that merit
Above her flattery: which she but practised
When I was interposed by greater accident
Than ever yet made learned error give her
The profane attributes of a deity.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: He surely doth suspect me.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Had I fallen
(As ten to one I might, had not the cause
Given me the greater odds.) Had you contrived it —

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: How's that! your jealousy is an unkindness
My love deserves not.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I hope you are not guilty,
That catch th' uncertain meaning of my words
Ere they are perfected; and preinterpret
Thoughts that had never being! I may then
Justly have doubts. For innocence unmoved
At a false accusation, doth the more
Confirm itself; and guilt is best discovered
By its own fears.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Pray fancy what you please
To strengthen your suspicion: 'tis indeed
So weakly grounded, that unless you prop it
With better circumstances, your own shame
Shall ruin it, and justify my truth.
I must out faced.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Your own impatience
May serve for one. This house you sent us to
For ought I know a brothel. You are noted
For one that surfeits in the pleasant sin:
And he that without scruple dares pursue it,
Dares without scruple do or be consenting
To any mischief from whose execution
The means may be derived that will maintain
His lust and riot.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: 'Tis not well that you
Digress from your first plea to this foul satire.
You should not tax my life, since it hath done you
Those offices deserve (Besides your thanks)
Your most indulgence to my greatest faults
Nor doth it show of noble nature in you
To credit infamy from a report,
Until confirmed by knowledge. Howsoever
You have declared yourself in your suspicion;
And hence forth I desist: my practises
Have been so fruitless. One I had contrived
to crown th' expression of my zealous care
In your affairs. You might have used my love
To better ends.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Pray sir continue it,
And reconcile your passions, he shall be
No more in such an error, to mistake
The aim of your intentions. From my warrant
He shall again be settled in's opinion
Of your fidelity, not to be altered
By after accidents.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: When once suspected,
Can I presume that any undertaking
Will be received well?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Prithee sweet remove
Th' ill grounded jealousy and hear him. He'll
Propose what may be useful.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: I shall never
But fear hereafter all my actions
Will not be fairly construed.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: It must be
By that fear only. Cousin I ne'er brought
My doubts to such a positive conclusion,
But that they might be changed to better truth
By your least satisfaction. If you have
Designed ought for our good, and that my judgement
Gives it allowance, no suspicion shall
Hinder the execution.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Might I be
Confirmed no misinterpretation should
Wrest the intent.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I am not capable
Of a new doubt, unless your doubts beget it.
Then pray impart your counsel.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Thus it is.
I have a little country house near Epping;
Thither I would convey you. You may there
Conceal yourself some time; in which I'll practise
A reconciliation with their loves
by all the means that my invention
Can work. Nor think I have sinister ends;
But fair, as ever perfect friendship made
Glorious in the success.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Prithee consent
To this fair motion.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Cousin to express
How far I am from fear of any treachery
You might be guilty of; what you advise to
Shall be put into instant act. This key
Will lead you where my husbandry hath stored
Something from honest gain, without least wronging
The old man's trust; I pray convey it hither
Where we'll expect you.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Please you to command
My store; what I am master of is yours.
I shall gain time to plot; my sudden policies
Wanted a right foundation.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: They are here an't please your worship.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: We are anew betrayed.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Mischief forbid it.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: You shall have justice fear it not.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: You may take my warrant gentlemen.

div.head: The second scene.
div.stage: To them the blades, justice Ferret, mrs. Ferret, and raven.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: The justice! then all's marred.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: What Mr. bridegroom?

sp.speaker: M. Fe.
sp.l: And mistress Bride! send you joy.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Are you the —

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fer.
sp.p: Let me speak sir parrot; must you be repeating your session's lecture, and I in place?

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.p:
The justice knows them. Best shift for yourselves lest you be found the most delinquents, and forced from your bower of pleasure here to peep through a grate or taste the
charity of Bridewell. Exeunt blades.

sp.speaker: M. Fe.
sp.l: You are complained of by these —

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Ha! whither are they gone that accused you?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Without their accusation I submit
Myself to th' law. And if you have direction
To use your power, let it acquit this gentlewoman
From the ensuing scandal, I'll be patient
With any punishment the just revenge
Of those I have so wronged can lay upon me.

sp.speaker: M. Fe.
sp.l: Is she not your wife?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Heaven hath forbid it, and my penitence
Restores her back.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: It shall not by my hopes
Of comfort in thy love. If your commission
Be for our apprehension. —

sp.speaker: M. Fe.
sp.p: Truly mistress Bride I should be glad to apprehend you in bed together: 'twas expected all had been cock sure by this. 'twas but a plot of your old foster father to pretend marrying her himself when he meant her only for you.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: They will discover all; curse on the accident
That brought them hither.

sp.speaker: M. Fe.
sp.p: To express it more fully, and how dear you are to him, he hath conferred his whole estate upon you. My worshipful husband's hand is to the writing.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: It is indeed sir.

sp.speaker: M. Fe.
sp.l: Is it so sir? as if my word were not sufficient!

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Hear them attentively, and then your care.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I do hear words that must be scanned and construed.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: He appointed that gentleman to find you out.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Amazement hath possessed me wholly.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Although my person came before you, sir,
You were the first deliverer of this joy,
Which I concealed for reasons: but desire
I now may finish all in private:

sp.speaker: M. Fer.
sp.l: Talk your fill sir, whilst I drink mine.Drinks.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Cousin I know you wonder at the strangeness
Of all: for which take this brief satisfaction.
You are betrayed to receive punishment,
for what you rather do deserve a crown.
This justice and myself had the instructions
All's nothing but a plot to get you back.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Why then would you pretending love conceal it?
And mock my fears with such diversity
Of dangerous accidents, you brought upon them?

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Alas had I revealed the circumstance
Of his professed love; feigned intentions
And the smooth traps were laid to catch you in,
I know your nature of such easy temper,
You rather would have flattered yourself
Into belief of them, than your own danger.
'Twas my prevention.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: How I shall determine,
And reconcile these differences to truth
Is hard. Be firm my resolution:
I will be satisfied, and yet prevent
The danger that is her. My cousin raven
Is certainly a villain. You have been sir
The comfortable messenger of pardon
That ere engaged a man; and if you please
To be the instrument of farther good,
You'll find us grateful.

sp.speaker: M. Fe.
sp.l: Command both me and mine husband.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Pray take this gentlewoman to your care,
Whilst I go back to make acknowledgement
Of the great benefits are done me.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: I will along with thee likewise.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: By no means ▪
Let him be satisfied of all that's past
Which I'll instruct him how without his danger,
Whilst you are absent.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Shall she be your charge?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: She shall go to our house.

sp.speaker: M. Fe.
sp.p: And welcome with my husband's good liking. To your house? as if the entertainment of constables on a sharing day were not chargeable enough, but you must compliment away wine and sweet meats. 'tis enough that we wish them well; let others do them good.

sp.speaker: F●
sp.l: Sweet wife 〈◊〉; I have found out another way.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Observe me sir, I will discover more.
D'ye think 'tis fit my cousin go alone sir?
Suppose those baffled roarers (Whom he did
Justly correct) way l●y him; may there not
Be danger in't?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: You say well sir. Standish and dash my clerks shall a long with him. Or what think you of my neighbour catch the marshals man? the sight of him would fright them.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Do you mark that sir he would have you guarded.
Would you were off: I'll tell you more by th' way.
I'll along with you cousin, so I may
Borrow a weapon.

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.l: You may have one of these.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Let's on; I will return to our full joys;
I go but to prepare them. And find out
The meaning of these riddles.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: My prayers go with thee. Exit.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: By this, what I intend shall be conferred
Upon those roarers, that will carry circumstance
To make it credited, and quit me wholly
Of all suspect. In mischief there's content,
When we on others lay the punishment. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Come mistress Bride, we will walk and see some rarities and antiquities till they return. There is one in the neighbourhood is stored with them; as if he had translated the capital hither.

sp.speaker: M. Fe.
sp.p: The motion's good: it should have been mine sir. You shall see the feathers of a phoenix; the beak of a pelican, and the skins of birds, beasts and fishes, stuffed with hay, enough to bring down the marker. For coins and medals he hath those with inscriptions that speak their date 500 years before the use of letters. He hath the fingers and toes of a colossus, and three hairs of a giant's upper lip, each of them as big as a bull rush. Then he hath the the members of a pygmy, that cannot be discerned but through a multiplying glass. Yet it is thought he would gladly part with all he hath for the philosophers stone; I or the unicorns horn at Windsor.

sp.speaker: F●.
sp.p: Come come, he hath those things a prince might glory to be owner of, and 'tis bravely done of him to affect them.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Such sights will be delightful. I must strive
In what I may my sad thoughts to withstand;
Which do presage some mischief's near at hand. Exit.

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.p: you're welcome with a mischief to the occasion that brought you hither. Here hath been attendance for a quart of wine and that not paid for. Some better customers, or I shall crack without credit. My blades baffled too! Their loss must be repaired upon the next advantage.

div.head: The third scene.
div.stage: To him Kickshaw like a gentleman.

sp.p: You are welcome sir.

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.p: Pray take a me cloak: me back be so hot, will burn a hole in it.

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.l: Would you have a cooler sir?

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.l: You understand for bien: de vench, de wench.

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.l: Excuse moy pur●la.

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.l: Parle Francois monsieur?

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.l: Non intendo.

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.p: You fall intand dat me be de French gentleman; dat me have two tre● crown in me pocket and the vuld have a de vine and de vench, and be merry in de chamber.

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.l: I'll send one to you sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.p: Remercy monsieur. Voe call a me cook now! de greasy larone! True; me make de franch dish for de lor: he give me two tree piece; me steal two tree piece of plate more, dat buy de for, de ha● an de seder; and Monsieur be so good a gentleman as —

div.head: The fourth scene.
div.stage: To him the blades, first one, then the rest and afterwards the wenches.

sp.speaker: 1 Bla.
sp.l: Who sit? Drawer brings in wine and exit.

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.l: Me have noting to say to you

sp.speaker: 1 Bla.
sp.l: I had thought you had sent for me.

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.l: You be no vench monsieur.

sp.speaker: 1 Bla.
sp.l: Would you have me to procure you one?

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.l: Me give you de vine and you fetch a de vench.

sp.speaker: 1 Bla.
sp.l: Do you take a blade for a pander?

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.l: You no quarrel vid me?

sp.speaker: 1 Bla.
sp.p: Yes and piss upon your back canopy, that shadows your half roasted kidneys if you dishonour a blade with the least suspicion. Yet in a fair way I care not to exchange a glass or two.

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.p: Vid all mine art. But pray Monsieur be you no so hot in de mout.

sp.speaker: 1 Bla.
sp.p: Do you disparage my tobacco? I assure you sir it is right Spanish.

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.l: Me can no endure de Spanish.

sp.speaker: 1 Bla.
sp.p: Not your blade? why your French temper will not bear an edge to chop rotten litter for mortar.

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.p: You speak not like a gentleman dat love not to be a all mode.

sp.speaker: 1 Bla.
sp.l: Pox on your mode

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.l: Dat be no good word Monsieur.

sp.speaker: 1 Bla.
sp.p: Doth it touch you sir? why 'tis your credit to be marked by that French herald for a gentleman of fashion.

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.p: Me can be no more patient. Me cut in two tree thousand piece for dishonour the French gentleman.

sp.speaker: 2 Bla.
sp.l: Will you so sir? we are for you. As he offers to draw, the blades come in and bind him.

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.l: O de base coward.

sp.speaker: 3 Bla.
sp.l: We shall be valiant enough to over come your metal.

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.l: Help help; de thieves rob me. Picks his pocket.

sp.speaker: 1 Bla.
sp.p:
No no monsieur, you shall have a vench for your money,
when you have entered into bonds for your good behaviour.

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.l: De gran English ●on you all ▪ vat you do vid me?

sp.speaker: 1 Bla.
sp.p: Work a cure (If we can) on the itch in your blood, that hath infected many of our wenches, and made them dangerous to us.

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.l: O diable! que faite vous?

sp.speaker: 2 Bla.
sp.l: He speaks ends out of a puppet play.

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.l: Help help; de thieves kill me beat me.

sp.speaker: 1 Bla.
sp.l: Peace monsieur; you shall have a wench presently.
Wine, music, and whilst you in dalliance, meet
We'll tread a measure with our nimble feet
Shall tempt you to be sportive, if desire
Want whetting and renew the active fire.
Come wenches. Monsieur there's a she for you.
Your meat is paid for; if you lik't fall to.

div.stage: Having taken away his m●ney, sword and belt they sing and dance about him, whilst an ill-favoured greasy wench offers sometimes to kiss him.

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.p: O fie fee. De thief, rogue poison me vid de stinking mackerel.

sp.speaker: 1 Bla.
sp.l: Let's leave him now t'his patience, and go share.
And when you want a wench to cool you monsieur,
You know where's those can take your courage down sir.Exeunt

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.p: O de villain, de laroone! my for an my money; and de slut leave a varse stink behind her den de fransh cook Kishin stuff

div.head: The fifth scene.
div.stage: To him squirrel.

sp.p: O Monsieur help me. Me go to de constable, and de beadle sall vip for dis.

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.p: What's here? how came you bound? Not for any good behaviour.

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.p: De thieves kill me and rob me. Fetch a me cloak, me go to de justice and his clerk. Fetch a me cloak I say.

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.p: Presently sir. But now I have released you, who shall pay the reckoning? 'tis five shillings you and your company have had in wine.

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.p: O diable! me no drink vine: de thief leave me no vine penny.

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.p: Your cloak then shall be your surety: it shall be forth coming when you please to release it.

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.l: I say ●ill have a me cloak.

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.p: Not till you have paid the reckoning. I am not to take notice of all men's behaviour; if you admit of company and they abuse you, you must suffer for it. I mean not sir to be overreached with any of your French cheats.

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.l: Is English cheat to send me no vench — but my cloak.

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.l: Not without the reckoning.

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.l: Me must den walk in cuerpo.

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.p: A fashion of your own, and apt to be followed upon the like occasion.

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.l: Me sall fetch de magistrate. Exit.

sp.speaker: Squi.
sp.p: Even whom you please. My correspondence with these blades and wenches helps me and themselves to many such purchases; yet still my house is honest. Though many will say,

lg.l: No matter how so they have coming in,
And sin thrives best that is maintained by sin. Exit.

div.head: The first scene.
div.stage: Maligo and Rhenish meeting Horten.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: It should be he by the description was made of him.

sp.speaker: Rhe.
sp.l: Let us salute him then. If your name be Horten sir?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I own no other.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: We are commended to you by some friends of yours, that request for us your leave to see rarities and antiquities you have, and for which you are so much spoken of abroad in the world.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: The world I do believe speaks grossly of me;
and calls my curiosity in reposing
Such things, a prodigal vainess being one
That lives by my endeavours: have no state
But what my labour purchaseth.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: May we have leave to walk to your house?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: And command
The sight of all. I must confess my care
Of knowing and possessing rarities
Makes me so skilful, I dare undertake
To pick a salad out of Dioscorides,
Shall feast the doctor's college, with rare practises
Stranger than aesons restitution
To youth by magic. From my garden sir
I can produce those simples, shall outwork
All the compounds of drugs, and show like miracles
Compared with them. What needs the weapon salve,
Condemned by some for witchcraft? when each dunghill
Affords the Persicaria, that on wounds
Works the like magic. Panax coloni
Is known to every rustic; and hypericon.
And yet we must from Memphis and Judea
Fetch balsam, though sophisticate; there is not
An ounce in Europe, will endure the trial
Of milk or water. Yet my lady's gentlewoman
Bitten by her monkey, swears by her lost maidenhead
The world hath not a balsam like to that
Her closet yields; when 'tis perhaps but oil
A little aromatised for lamps.

sp.speaker: Rhe.
sp.l: You are learned likewise in antiquities.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: A little sir.
I should affect them more, were not tradition
One of the best assurances to show
They are the things we think them. What more proofs
(Unless perhaps a little circumstance)
Have we for this or that to be a piece
Of delphos ruins? or the marble statues
Made Athens glorious, when she was supposed
To have more images of men than men?
A weatherbeaten stone with an inscription
That is not legible but through an optic,
Tells us i●s age; that in some Sibyl's cane
Three thousand years ago it was an altar.
'Tis satisfaction to our curiosity;
But ought not to necessitate belief.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Antiquities fir are grown of late good merchandise.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Th' affection of some princes hath begotten
An imitation, and 'tis nobly done.
For by such things man's knowledge is informed
In principles of art, and many times
They light upon instruction by them, that
Direct invention to recover what
Neglect or ignorance hath lost.

sp.speaker: Rhe.
sp.l: Pray sir what are the rarities and antiquities you have?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Nor Pliny fir, nor Gesner ever made
Description of a creature, but I have
Some particle thereof: and for antiquity
I do not store up any under Grecian.
Your Roman antiques are but modern toys
Compared to them. Besides, they are so counterfeit
With mouldings, 'tis scarce possible to find
Any but copies.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Yet you are confident of yours that are of more doubt.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Others from their easiness
May credit what they please. My trial's such
Of any thing I own, all the impostors
That ever made antiquity ridiculous
Cannot deceive me. If I light upon
Ought that's above my skill, I have recourse
To those whose judgements at the second view
(If not the first) will tell me what philosophers
That eyeless, noseless, mouthless statue is,
And who the workman was, though since his death
Thousands of years have been revolved —

div.head: The second scene.
div.stage: To them justice Ferret, Mrs. Ferret and bride.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: A good evening to you neighbour Horten.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: And to your worship.

sp.speaker: M. Fe.
sp.l: My husband will still be before me, to prevent the amen of a shrew. Fer. and Hort. whisper.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: You are happily met mistress Bride.

sp.speaker: Rhe.
sp.p: But 'tis my sudden wonder what accident should guide her this way.

sp.speaker: M. Fe.
sp.p: These gentlemen are witnesses to the old man's deeds, as well as my worshipful husband

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: The fortune of this day hath led me through
Events both strange and dangerous. I hope
As you are gentlemen that you will make
A fair construction of me, though the vulgar
Borrow discourse and pastime from my act.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: You are a brave woman. Yet had I opportunity —

sp.speaker: Rhe.
sp.l: She is sure a light heeled wench, and if —

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: With all my heart and welcome.

sp.speaker: M. Fe.
sp.p: Are you making motions now, before I can recover breath to begin my exordium as my son at the university taught me to say. Neighbour Horten 'tis thus. Myself and my husband have this day been eyewitnesses of strange accidents; chance upon chance, and fortune upon fortune: one disaster hath been the cause and cure of another. Now we desire the favour that we may see your trinkets, knacks and knaveries (Pardon me neighbour I mean no hurt) to delight this melancholic gentlewoman that hath found and lost, and lost and found a husband yet no husband —

sp.speaker: Hort
sp.l: You shall command me: but she chiefly.

sp.speaker: M. Fe.
sp.l: And shall we see all?

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: All I assure you.

sp.speaker: M. Fe.
sp.p: The great sea horse what you call that cures women of the cramp.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: What a wanton tempting eye she hath?

sp.speaker: Rhe.
sp.l: I will attempt her.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: A handsome lass. I must have her home and give her a philtre.

div.head: The third scene.
div.stage: To them Kickshaw.

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.l: Vich be de justice?

sp.speaker: M. Fe.
sp.l: What justice sir?

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.l: Justice vat you call run up and down de coney hole.

sp.speaker: M. Fe.
sp.l: My husband's name is ferret: what's your business sir?

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.p: De he thief and de she thief rob me at vat you call de little nutcrack house? and he take a me cloak an me have no vare for my money.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: I know the house he means; a place much suspected. But a few hours since there happened a dangerous up roar about this gentlewoman; and the delinquents came to complain first. But had they not conveyed themselves away, they should have been punished.

sp.speaker: M. Fe.
sp.p: With what trow? A reproof or a jeer out of your table book notes, enlarged with a piece of a charge; then with a half bribe and single fees they are released to boast how cheap they have scaped. Come come you shall back to this house, and be severe, and wise and say little, let mine be the speaking part, yours the doing: I'll make them come off and on roundly. Do you think I can keep house with bare warrants and mittimuses?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Will you with us neighbour?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I desire to be excused.

sp.speaker: M. Fer.
sp.l: By all means neighbour; you are an officer.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: What shall become of this gentlewoman then?

sp.speaker: M. Fe.
sp.p: Please these gentlemen to walk a turn or two with her? The evening's pleasant if the mist rise not.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I had rather I had her at home.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: We are her servants.

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.l: Is define vench.

sp.speaker: M. Fe.
sp.l: We will along with you sir to this righteous —

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Riotous you would say.

sp.speaker: M. Fe.
sp.p: No sir 'tis riotous place; and my husband shall ferret the he thieves and the she thieves holes never fear it.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: To have seen this wench and not to enjoy her, is such a tantalising to me. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.p: Me sall turn back again from you to dis fine vench. Me give her my doublet cost two tree pound for lie vid her two tree time. O fine vench! Exit.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: 'Tis most opportune.

sp.speaker: Rhen.
sp.l: Could I but remove him?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Please you to walk, and let my hand support you.

sp.speaker: Rhe.
sp.l: Please her to be my charge. They strive which should lend bride

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I'll be your servant lady.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: What mean ye gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: To do you manly service.

sp.speaker: Rhe.
sp.l: If you could sir.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: How sir?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: I am betrayed unto a new misfortune.
There is a malice in the stars that guide me,
Which yet seem wanton, as their influence
Were but a sportive mockery to show
The various fates that do depend upon it.
I have had strange deliverance; but th' event
Of this is full of horror. I pray gentlemen
Do not make me the object for a quarrel.
Your gravity should be judicious,
And not mind trifles: such as youthful blood
Heated with wine can no way be excused for.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: He shall not touch you his belly is nothing but a tun full of red herring, and boyld water.

sp.speaker: Rhe.
sp.l: And thou art a rotten herring jack-a-lent Spaniard.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: A word in private. They go aside, and seem to threaten and challenge one another.

sp.speaker: Rhen.
sp.l: What you dare sir.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: A challenge sure. Some happy chance direct
Aid to prevent a mischief:Kickshaw returns.

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.l: Me be your servant madam.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Would you would guide me to some house?

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.l: To de house of good fellowship, or de nax dish.
Here be de fine moral.
Viles Dutch and Spanish make a fray
De Frenchman bear de pri●e a way. Exit. with bride.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: You'll meet me then?

sp.speaker: Rhe.
sp.l: I will not fail you.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: But where's the gentlewoman? where hath the mist concealed you?

sp.speaker: Rhe.
sp.l: We have differed finely about a woman in a cloud.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: We must not so lose her.

div.head: The fourth scene
div.stage: To them Theophilus and Raven.

sp.speaker: Rhe.
sp.l: Saw you a gentlewoman sir?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Her sweet heart! let us avoid him lest we be discovered.

sp.speaker: Rhe.
sp.p: I'll home and be drunk, and then perhaps grow friends with you. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: The merchants? were they not?

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Doubtless the same.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: What gentlewoman should that be they asked for?

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.p: Some bonaroba they have been sporting with. Your outlandish merchants are notable barterers for such English ware many of them keep their recreations at pension; and sometimes two copartners will share as even nightly.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: That's strange; if love will brook no rivals, lust should being the more raging passion.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: 'Tis common.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: How common?

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Wenching is like friendship hath all things common.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: The mist is great: have we not lost our way?
We might ere this have got to th' water's side
Though we had trod a labyrinth. Raven draws and runs at Theophilus, and he turning back wounds Rau.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Over this stile and then

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Ha! what devil moved thee to attempt it.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Pox on these French blades; no point!
I have paid a debt to all my vain attempts
With mine own ruin. Hell hath left me yet
One means to express my malice. In my death
Die to all knowledge of thyself; the world
Besides me owns it not -Falls and lies as if he were dead.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I cannot give
Utterance unto my thoughts; the narrow passage
Is choked up with a multitude, that strive
Which should first issue forth. How fruitless envy
Brings on its own destruction! Innocence
Is proof 'gainst all the battery of malice:
And he that's armed with't needs not fear to encounter
The most severe tribunal. Though I am
Guiltless to heaven, yet I shall appear
Foul to opinion wanting testimony;
And th' act makes me the laws; I am no more
The subject of my conscience, which by judgement
Must be determined. Can I not prevent it?
Flight may procure my safety. 'twill bring on
A greater danger, and cause supposition
That I am guilty by the circumstance
Of mine own fears.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: Help, help, a rape. Villain keep back.
