sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Horrors on both sides round me.
Hath my cross fortune found new instruments
To draw more mischiefs on me! By the voice
(A woman's weakly uttered, as if fainting
Under some violence) 'tis near this hedge.
I'll aid her, though my ruin lay in ambush
With twenty murderers.

div.head: The fifth scene.
div.stage: To them bride pursued by Kickshaw.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Out villain:
Would I could spit a leprosy upon thee.
Help help. Kickshaw falls on his knees, and bride holds back Theophilus

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: My dearest!

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.l: O pardon moy monsieur.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Villain thy end's upon thee.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: I being safe
Prithee forbear him.

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.l: Is no fair play for give me de prick monsieur.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: How cam'st thou hither sweet?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Soon as my fears
Have finished their effects of trembling,
And that my breath's recovered, shalt know all.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Monsieur stir not; I have employment for you
May win your pardon.

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.p: Vid all mine art; but mine art vill be in mine eel anon; is fallen already into me breeshes.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: What object's this? Alas your cousin raven
Wounded or dead? what hand hath done it?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: This;
Justice made this her instrument. He was
A villain to me, and betrayed my life
To all those dangers which I overcame
By th' cause's strength. And lastly his intents
To murder me, have brought upon himself
This punishment as due.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Why dost not fly then?
I'll bear thee company in all adversities.
Thy person being safe time may effect
A pardon by some composition.
If thou be ta'en, thou meetest thy certain end
Mingled with shame; and mine hath the same date:
I'll not out live thee.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Did you bid me fly
To shun the end's before me? sure there's difference
Twixt meritorious acts, and acts of shame.
I was but justice executioner.
His crime deserved death, and he had fair trial
By evidence: see here this pointless weapon;
If providence had not ordained it so.
As he so I had fallen; but innocent.
Should I then fly? and by my fears beget
A worse suspicion? No: I'll meet th' event.
And though I now were circled with the terrors
Of racks and tortures; gibbets; executioners;
And all the palsying apprehensions
That ever made a malefactor tremble,
Armed as I am, I would encounter all
With a fixed confidence. Just causes never
Did yet miscarry; or if any have
'Twas to the greater glory of the cause.
And Monsieur 'tis your imposition
To watch this corpse, and give to passengers
What answers you have wit or language for.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Wilt thou not fly then? prithee do not rashly
Play away safety.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: If I fly, and so
Provide for't, will you with me?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.l: Even to death,
In that 'Shalt find me resolute. I'll vy
Against thy courage with my constancy.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Let's go thenExeunt.

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.p: Me be glad you be gone, for me will no stay long vid de dead man. If de live jentelvmanly so — but me sall see vat you have in your pocket. Kickshaw searching raven's pocket he stirs.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: O? A surgeon.

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.p: De man be no dead: but me sall make you dead rader den go vidout your money. Kick. offers to take the sword from raven and he riseth.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: What wilt thou villain?
'Tis time then to leave off counterfeiting

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.p: Dis be de gentleman hire me to work at de wedding; but he no know me, and day be sure de gentleman and de jenteluman da● run avay together.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: I'm wounded, but I hope not mortally;
I have no feeling of those accidents
Are deaths forerunners. Would I had a surgeon.
If I survive, I will convert this mischief
Into a benefit; and by his flight
possess myself as well of what I cove●,
As by his death. Sir you can witness for me
How and by whom I did receive this wound.
Although you know him not, make a description.

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.l: Pardon me Monsieur; me no see him do it.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: You must dispense with scruple
If you will serve my purposes a little,
I can and will be thankful; otherwise
Whate'er you are I can betray your life
For your intent of rape.

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.p: Me be your servant monsieur. Me do any ting; swear any ting; go to de devil along vid you rader den be hang.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Go with me to a surgeon.

div.head: The sixth scene.
div.stage: To them Goodlove with three or four servants.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: We need make greater haste; 'tis almost night;
The mist is risen much.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: My uncle's voice. Help a surgeon: assist me now.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: Look about knaves: I have heard that voice.

sp.speaker: 1 servant
sp.l: Here sir a man wounded.

sp.speaker: 2 servant
sp.l: 'Tis master raven.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: My cousin raven? what misfortune brought
This ill upon him? hold that gentleman.

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.p: Me no do it Monsieur: he be de young gentleman in black, an de jenteluman.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: What gentleman in black? Theophilus?

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: My cousin sir? alas; there's so much goodness
In him, I must not think he could be tempted
To wear such guilt about him. Good sir have me
Unto a surgeon; and that gentleman
Shall give you satisfaction, ere you give
Him a release.

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.l: Now me sall be discover, and hang for thief.

sp.speaker: 1 servant
sp.p: We 'I carry him to one hortens house, and fetch a surgeon thither: 'tis close by.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: One call my friend justice ferret; and post you over to mistress bride's father: his presence at the examination of these circumstances will be needful. Till truth satisfies my desires I am in torment.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: I have a new design.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: And till I see
Theophilus.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Which I hope never will be.

div.stage: Exeunt.

div.head: The first scene.
div.stage: Goodlove, Ferret, Mrs. Ferret, and Horten.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: Sir we are troublesome: the accident
Hath made a subject for your charity
As well as for your art; and neither shall
Be unrewarded. But may I presume
He'll need no other surgeon?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Doubt it not sir.
The wound's but slight; were it more dangerous,
The simples that I have applied would cure it
According to the first intention
As surgeons call it.

sp.speaker: M. Fer.
sp.p: Truly sir my neighbour is very skilful; he cured my little shock of the mange so perfectly, that it hath famed him through the neighbourhood for an excellent dog-leech.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I owe much to your commendation Mrs ferret.

sp.speaker: M. Fe.
sp.l: Truly neighbour 'tis not so much worth.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: I dare be sworn it is not.
I dare not with much confidence rely
Upon this man's endeavours. Would I had
A surgeon here, whose judgement and experience
Might give me further satisfaction.
Is the French gentleman disposed of safely?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I have confined him to a chamber sir,
A too delightful prison. He may feast
His eyes with rarities.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: I think you are
Owner of more than all the town besides.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: 'Tis my affected riches.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: I have some
You shall command sir.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I'll have gratitude,
And something to exchange. This accident
May bring me in a purchase:

sp.speaker: M. Fe.
sp.p: Pray neighbour let's see the late giants boot, and the dwarves shoe.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: Pretty extremes no doubt.

sp.speaker: M. Fe.
sp.p: Extremes sir! methinks their differences should make a very good mean. Suppose the one was a great drinker or wencher; the other must needs be a little one. What the one wasted in boots the other saves in shoes. But I'll in to the wounded gentleman, and help to talk away his pain.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: By no means: sleep would give him more ease, and prevent a distraction; which he seems to occasion some fear of by his often digressions and interruptions of discourse.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: Indeed sir I am troubled when I weigh
The accident and circumstances of it.
Nor can we urge him to give satisfaction
With any positive truth, but all his answers
Are careless and imperfect; many times
The second contradicts the first: and then
He'll name Theophilus, as if he were
The mischief's worker. But of all kind friends
Your strange relations have begotten most wonder.
The roarers, and Theophilus brave act;
My cousins not revealing my intents;
The maid left with the merchants, and the monsieurs
Stealing away, then found with my hurt kinsman,
What to conclude from these —

div.head: The second scene.
div.stage: To them a servant hastily.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: The news! what means your haste?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: A lass sir you are robbed.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: How's that?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: The French gallant sir which you locked in the chamber, is run away with your remoras and Torpedos skins; and we know not what besides.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Pursue him. I'd not lose those rarities
For half my state. Alas sir they are valuable
Above any thing I own besides.

sp.speaker: M. Fe.
sp.p: Hath Monsieur given you the slip as he gave us? He may chance be caught in a halter for it.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: Be patient sir, and with your best endeavour
Restore my cousin to his former safety,
I'll recompense your loss with things more valuable.
I have large trees of coral, and zibetas
Both of strange form and colour; I expect
Some living ermines.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Would I had them, they
Should pacify me quickly,

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: Sure that French man
Is guilty of the fact: why should he fly else?
If by your servants industry that Monsieur
May be brought back again, 'twill be of consequence.
Something perhaps may be concluded from
A strict examination of him.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I'll employ all the servants I have about it.

sp.speaker: M. Fe.
sp.p: They shall have my husband's authority with them; we'll make you a warrant. Exeunt. Good. rema.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: How various are th' events that may depend
Upon one action, yet the end proposed
Not follow the intention! Accidents
Will interpose themselves; like those rash men
that thrust into a throng occasioned
By some tumultuous difference, where perhaps
Their busy curiosity begets
New quarrels with new issues. I go on
From one consideration to another,
Yet can determine nothing.

div.head: The third scene.
div.stage: To him father, mother and servant. Your arrival will be of use fir.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.l: Else my pains were fruitless.
Chance brought us hither, for what ends I know not.
But understanding you were here, I come
To ask a daughter from you.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: I from you
Must have a wounded reputation cured,
It bleeds worse than my kinsman, whom your son
And daughter are by circumstance suspected
To have attempted.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.l: My son said you sir?
I hear that son of mine must be your heir;
And I have heard what plots and circumventions
You used to catch me: so you have sir finely.
My states mine own still, though my daughter's lost.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: And pray sir keep it; doubt not but 'twill find
Some grateful heir, that will preserve the memory
Of such a benefit, with witty libels
Upon your glorious life.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.l: Your scorn is well sir;
And well becomes that supercilious gravity,
Hath awed the city long, and frighted rats
Into the counter.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: You are very free sir.
Yet these are not the city's liberties.
Stand not too much upon your privilege.
If you can give fair satisfaction
For what concerns you, do; and let not passion
Kindle a new flame. I am calm; have quenched
My spleen that late was fired.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.l: I acknowledge
I ●eare your kinsman's wounded, and there is
A supposition by my daughter's sweet heart.
But how far this concerns me, be yourself
The judge. Sir I have suffered in my fame already
Too much, to have more added by suspicion
Of being accessary to an act
Of such vile nature; and yourself may sooner
Prove guilty, if the circumstance be weighed
You have made him your heir.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: My intention
Had done it; neither did it want the form
Of law for confirmation: but 'twas when
I was too partial in affection: now
I am resolved to satisfy that error
With severe justice.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.l: You'll revoke your act!

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: Hands stained with blood shall never have the power
To make a distribution of that wealth
Heaven hath blessed my fair endeavours with.
Should he be proved a murderer (For though
My cousin die not, his intent was such)
Revenge would wait on all his actions;
And even his charity when he gave alms
Would to his conscience so present the fact
In bloody characters, that his best deeds
Would lose their merit.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.l: I am hard put to it.
But sir suppose your kinsman did attempt
Some practice upon him; there's circumstance
To make it probable. Suppose your cousin
Repining at it that you should prefer
Adoption before natural succession,
assaulted him first to remove him, who
Defending so himself made the act lawful.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: From your suppose I raise a supposition,
That he to clear himself of after troubles
Which might arise by any kinsman's claim,
Attempted this prevention by some others
If not himself: which yet we cannot urge
My kinsman to discover.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.l: There are plots
In these proceedings. Might I sir be witness
To an examination of your kinsman?
The knowledge of the truth is of some consequence
And doth concern us.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: If he may endure
Discourse without his danger.

div.head: The fourth scene
div.stage: To them servant, plaster, and then Ferret, mrs. Ferret, and Horten.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Here's Mr. Plaster, the learned surgeon, that speaks nothing but Latin, because either he would not be understood, or not contradicted.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: He is welcome.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: There is no need sir of his trouble: the gentleman is past danger.

sp.speaker: Plaster
sp.l: Are you a surgeon sir?

sp.speaker: M. Fe.
sp.p: A simple one sir; one I mean that useth no compounds.

sp.speaker: Plaster
sp.p: If you are rational as well as empirical, and that you practice secundum artem 'tis well.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: I dare secure his safety.

You may err sir. He hath a wound; and where there is continuitatis divortium, you must consider whether it came per contusionem, punctionem, or how; and whether a nerve, tendon, ligament or artery be in danger. The parts likewise whether it be in principalibus vel minus principalibus. Then the adjuncts; whether there be fractura or dislocatio; for these make it vulnus compositum.
Then the accidents; whether there be inflammatio ochinos o● ▪

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: Pray sir what is that?

sp.speaker: Plaster
sp.p: It is sir copiosa sanguines inter cutem diffusio; which many times causeth a dangerous apostema

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: You have satisfied very well sir.

sp.speaker: Plaster
sp.p: Perhaps you have applied some mountebanks medicine which you believe will cure secundum primam intentionem.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: Pray sir how is that?

sp.speaker: Plaster
sp.p: That is sine suppuratione vel cicatrice. We that work according to art begin with alteration substantiae in p●s: for ex corruption unius fit generatio alterius. And then —

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: You have said enough sir more than we understand.
Pray sir give him leave to see my cousin and his wound: his judgement being a professor may confirm us.

div.head: The fifth scene.
div.stage: To them raven.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: He is here sir.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.p: The bride's father and a surgeon! what new device is towards? Fat. and Serv. whisper.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: I'll apply but one emplastrum consolidans more: I think that's a term of art. Exit. s●r.

sp.speaker: Plaster
sp.l: I come not to be jeered.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: To be rewarded; accept of this sir.Gives him money.

sp.speaker: Plaster
sp.p: My thankfulness. This is more than my practice would have deserved; for to say truth though I can out face it with talking, though I am neither parson nor vicar yet my cures serve to maintain sextons.
I take my leave sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: The wound was very slight sir.

sp.speaker: M. F●.
sp.p: Indeed Mr. raven you escaped a scouring in your belly: if you had miscarried, the monsieur for all the separation betwixt his doublet and breeches should have trust for't, but that he is run away.

sp.l: Escaped I'm glad of that: it shall be useful.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: Being passed danger cousin ▪ we would gladly
Be satisfied who 'twas that did attempt
This mischief on you: you have hitherto
Seemed as unwilling he should be discovered.
If 'twere Theophilus, all diligence
Shall be employed to find him, that he may
Pay law her due: his flight makes it suspicious.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Good sir forbear that trouble.
If he be fled with his fair mistress, 'tis
A discreet policy to shun the danger,
Her parents anger might bring on him. 'twas
The French man wounded me.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: On what occasion?

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: None sir that I know: I provoked him not;
Unless he meant to rob me.

sp.speaker: Fa●.
sp.l: Will you sir
Justify this on oath? Father's servant returns.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Were there necessity:
'Tis otherwise sufficient I have said it.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.l: Bring in the monsieur.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: How sir! is he taken!

sp.speaker: Father
sp.l: Yes sir; with many trinkets that were yours.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I am restored to my first state.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.l: We met him:
And for some reason you shall know anon
Brought him back with us.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: I am still discovered.

div.head: The sixth scene.
div.stage: To them Kickshaw.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.l: 'Tis needful sir this man should be committed;
That being accused he may be soon produced
Upon occasion.

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.p:
Me have no ●or to kill de man: de teeves have mine, true; me take de jenteluman from de dutchman and de Spaniard:
me offer too to kiss de jenteluman; an de young gentleman in black dat hurt de man, almost kill ●e but dat me beg pardon.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: I have lighted upon it.
Unto you all I do submit myself,
And what I shall discover. I confess
I may seem not to merit a belief
That have already feigned so many untruths:
But the officiousness of them considered
I hope you'll credit this. It was my cousin
Theophilus, that hurt me: but I know not
Whether 'twere chance or malice for this gentleman
Attempting rape upon your daughter sir,
I drew a pointless weapon I had got;
My cousin's sudden apprehension
Perhaps mad him suspect me: and not knowing
I meant a rescue of the gentlewoman
(Whose voice I heard, but could not through the ●ist
Discern her person) made his rash hand wound me;
Which for his sake I joy is not proved mortal,
Nor will I hope.

sp.speaker: F●t.
sp.l: I do believe all this
For certain truth. But why should you accuse
Another then?

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: I did presume this man
Unknown to any here was fled, nor would
Return to take a punishment: and being
A stranger was not capable of shame.
Now my concealing who the actor was
Neither his danger nor disgrace would follow.

sp.speaker: God.
sp.l: Nephew I do admire thy love to him
So ill deserves it, and I now consider
What an injustice my election was.
Henceforth thou art mine heir. I will employ
A numerous search to find him that he may
Be punished for his ●act.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: By no means sir:
Call him not back; my wound may yet have danger;
And if he should return to pay his life
for mine that's so unworthy —

sp.speaker: Father
sp.l: But he shall
To make you give the law a satisfaction
For all your villainies. Come forth my son,
For so he is sir.

div.head: The last scene.
div.stage: To them Theophilus and bride.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Humbly thus I begTheo. kneels
Your pardon sir

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: Pray ask your father blessing:
You've got one now.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.l: He hath sir, and shall keep him
His fair desert won my conversion;
And changed me from intents of punishing
To an indulgent favourer. This hath been
A villain to his life, and to his fortunes;
Whetted by envy to such practises
As merit death when you shall hear the passages.
A man that's guilty; that from foul intents
Proceeded to an act would fly for safety:
Instead of which Theophilus repaired
To me, that then was labouring with revenge,
First offers restitution of my daughter;
Then passing on from declaration
To declaration, made so confident
By his sweet innocence, he satisfied
Mine anger, and gave peace unto my passions
Nor was I patient to defer their joys
(Which likewise are mine own but got them married
This evening with a dispensation for it
Before we came to you. Where by the way
We met this Monsieur, and enforced him back:
Whom straight his fears betrayed to a discovery
Of what he was; no gentleman, but kickshaw
in's wenching clothes.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Monsieur Kickshaw want plate monsieur.

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.l: Now me sall be hang again.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: And I want jewels monsieur.

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.p: Jewels! me have noting but two tree babble. Pray vat be dis? Pulls the things out of his pockets.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: A babble call you it? This gentlemen is the horn of an Aethiopian rhinoceros.

sp.speaker: Kick.
sp.l: An dis!

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: The Talon of a bird in terra australi incognita, which the inhabitants call their great god ruc, that preys upon elephants, and will not be gorged under two or three in a morning this stone of a strange form and colour was brought by the learned traveller of Odcombe from the great mogul.

sp.speaker: M. Fe.
sp.l: How sir! One of the great mogul's stones,

sp.speaker: Father
sp.l: Good sir forbear a little. Now he's mine
I'll own him and the rather if you will
Disclaim all interest in him. For your kinsman
Some wise and powerful authority
Must force truth from him.

sp.speaker: M. Fe.
sp.l: My husband's authority sir is both wise and powerful

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: 'Tis not in all my stock of cunning now
To hold out longer. Shame will be the end
Of all my undertakings.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: Cousin your looks are strange, and seem as if
They would betray your thoughts. If you have guilt,
Let it not press your conscience with a weight
Will sink it into horror.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: I have much sir.
Nor will there need another testimony
For confirmation of what I shall utter.
He that with grief doth publish his own shame,
Speaks from truth's records.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: What may this preface mean?

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: You had a son, whose birth deprived his mother
Of life; and what bestowed a joy upon you
Robbed you of one.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: Why dost review a grief
time had worn out? Indeed I had a son.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: And have him still: enjoy him in Theophilus.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Was this the knowledge of myself he spoke of,
That lived but in himself?

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: I fear his wound,
And a distraction.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: Hear me sir and than
You will have faith. The child you did dispose
To be nursed by my mother, I being then
An infant likewise. She knowing by law
That I was capable of your estate
Your heir being once removed, soon plots
To make the child away; attempts, but fainting
In th' execution left it in the fields;
A formal burial strengthening the report
That it was dead. By providence directed
You found and bred it up, and this is he.
My dying mother did reveal it to me
With tears of penitence, and an injunction
I should discover it: which my avarice
And envy would not suffer me, but tempted
My soul to those black practises, which now
Cease with my shame and my repentance.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: JoysGood. embraceth Theo. kneeling.
Have filled me to the danger of a surfeit.
Welcome to life; I have a new begotten thee.
How often have I wished in these embraces
The thing I did embrace but knew it not.
Cousin I hope your sorrow is not feigned
That it may merit pardon, and preserve me
A loving uncle.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I forgive you cousin,
You have at length in this discovery
Given large satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Rau.
sp.l: I'll remove
All cause of after jealousy.

sp.speaker: Father
sp.l: We by theseGood. and fat ▪ embrace.
Are reconciled for ever.

sp.speaker: M. Fe.
sp.l: But here's a delinquent must be punished.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.l: He shall be pardoned ●o upon condition
He will no more play the impostor thus,
To wear the habit of a gentleman
Having such vile conditions; ●o disgracing
His noble nation; making all suspected.
I'll likewise add something unto your storehouse.
And though 'tis late let's have a wedding feast:
To which pray welcome every loving guest.

lg.l: I am a maiden yet, how can I then
Without some fear and blushes speak to men?
Ladies and gentlewomen pray stick to me
If the rude men should offer to undo me.
Would they be kind, and say I have done well
I'd give them leave to clap me. I can tell
They'd take it for a favour if they might
Clap every bride upon her wedding night.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
